attachments.displayName:
This time we’re looking at: The Lost World.

One day, when Adam and Eve were in the garden, a serpent appeared and began talking to Eve. The Bible says that the serpent was “more cunning than any beast of the field which the LORD God had made.” (Genesis 3:1) Serpents were the most intelligent animal that existed. We don’t know what exactly they were like before the fall, but we do know they didn’t move only on their stomachs. That was a part of the curse. (Genesis 3:14) Some people think they were able to talk, probably because the Bible records no suggestion that Eve was surprised when it started speaking. (We don’t really know, but they could have been intelligent enough that it wouldn’t alarm Eve anyway.)

The serpent was occupied by Satan himself. Revelation 20:3 calls him “the dragon, that serpent of old, who is the Devil and Satan.” He came up to Eve, not Adam - the authority, and began talking to her. Think carefully about what he said: “Has God indeed said, 'You shall not eat of every tree of the garden'?” (Genesis 3:1) The Hebrew word there literally means “from any.” He was changing God’s words. God had told Adam he could eat of every tree, except the one in the center of the garden. God gave this to Adam and Eve as a test, to show their love for Him. God could have created man with no free will, but then they wouldn’t be able to express their love for him by choosing to obey.

Eve replied, “‘We may eat the fruit of the trees of the garden; but of the fruit of the tree which is in the midst of the garden, God has said, “You shall not eat it, nor shall you touch it, lest you die.”’

Then the serpent said to the woman, ‘You will not surely die. For God knows that in the day you eat of it your eyes will be opened and you will be like God, knowing good and evil.’” Genesis 3:2-5

It was true that Adam and Eve would not die right away, but they would begin to die. As soon as God’s perfect presence and order was removed from the world, all of creation would begin to decline. They would begin to understand good and evil, but that was not something good. Instead of simply trusting and obeying God, they would rely on their own finite understanding to make decisions.

She doubted that God really wanted the best for them. Why would He keep them back from something that appeared to be good? Was God jealous, and wanted to keep them dependent? “So then the woman saw that the tree was good for food, that it was pleasant to the eyes, and a tree desirable to make one wise, she took of its fruit and ate. She also gave to her husband with her, and he ate.” Genesis 3:6

Can you imagine that moment when God looked down and saw Eve take that fruit? To see His own creation, to which He gave everything they ever needed to be satisfied, doubt and disobey Him? To break this perfect fellowship they had always had with Him, to go their own way? God could see, down through the ages, the Messiah - God’s own precious Son, whom He would send out of His unending love to redeem His undeserving children.
